items.description: Upper Bristol Avon area
items.message:
River levels are now falling on the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon, Dauntsey Brook but are due to rise again this evening due to more rainfall. 

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon, Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around the road at Reybridge. 

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area and we will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 02/01/2024 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Blackwater and The Cove Brook
items.message:
River levels remain high on the River Blackwater as a result of a period of sustained rain.  Flooding of low lying land is expected to continue. The forecast for today (05/01/24) is for mostly dry conditions with the chance of some light showers tonight.  Levels are already beginning to fall at the top of the river catchment, and this will will continue over the next 24 hours.                                        A Flood Warning remains in force for the River Loddon and River Blackwater at Swallowfield.                                                                                                                           

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Rivers Deben and Lark
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Friday 5th January 2024. River levels are currently high in places as the river responds to recent rainfall.  Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas on the Deben from Debenham to Ufford, including Framsden, Earl Soham, Easton, Glevering and Wickham Market, and on the Rivers Lark and Finn around Witnesham, Tuddenham St Martin, Playford and Grundisburgh.   The forecast is for predominantly dry weather with some isolated showers for the next few days. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation closely.  We will update this message tomorrow, Saturday 6th January.

items.description: River Lavant
items.message: The River Lavant is high, but stable, following Thursday's rain. Minor flood impacts will continue to affect fields, rural roads and gardens. Including Sheepwash Lane, Pook Lane and the Green in East Lavant. Access bridges across the river could be affected. Flooding is not expected at The Sadlers in Westhampnett or Chichester City Centre. Very little rain is forecast for the next five days. The river is expected to remain fairly stable over the coming week, but could rise a couple of centimetres from the present level, because groundwater upstream is rising. River levels should begin to slowly drop by 10/01/2024, but will be higher than normal throughout January. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding including Sheepwash Lane. If you see a blockage affecting the flow in the river, please call our incident hotline on 0800 80 70 60. We are managing structures in Westhampnett to operate the River Lavant Flood Alleviation scheme to reduce the flood risk on the River Lavant. We will update this message by 14:00 06/01/2024.

items.description: River Severn in Gloucestershire
items.message:
River levels continue to rise on the River Severn as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue over the next few days. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. 

Predicted peaks:-

Mythe, 4.7m to 4.8m this morning, Friday 05/01/2024. 
Haw Bridge, 5.7m to 5.8m this morning, Friday 05/01/2024. 	
Sandhurst, 5.0m to 5.1m this morning, Friday 05/01/2024. 
Gloucester docks, 4.6m to 4.7m this morning, Friday 05/01/2024. 

We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 

This message will be updated by 7pm today, Friday 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Rivers Box and Brett
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Friday 5th January. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas on the River Box from Little Waldingfield to Thorrington Street, including Boxford, and on the River Brett from Cockfield to Higham, including Hadleigh. River levels are beginning to fall, but will remain responsive to further rainfall. The forecast for the next few days is for predominantly dry weather, but with some isolated showers. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation closely. We will update this message tomorrow, Saturday 6th January 2024.

items.description: Lower River Soar in Leicestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Kegworth and Pillings river gauges as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads around Loughborough, Zouch, Kegworth, Ratcliffe on Soar to Redhill Marina, the A6006 at Zouch, Soar Lane Sutton Bonnington, Moor Lane Normanton, Station Road at Kegworth, Kegworth Road and The Green Ratcliffe on Soar.
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.
This message will be updated by this evening, 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Aire catchment
items.message: This Flood Alert has now been removed. River levels in the Upper River Aire catchment have continued to fall overnight and are expected to continue falling through today, Friday 5th January 2024. Levels in washlands are likely to remain high but gradually drop as we go into the weekend. No significant further rainfall is forecast. We will continue to monitor the situation and our operational staff will be out checking our flood defences. Please continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Keswick Campsite
Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
River and lake levels whilst continuing to recede, do remain high due to recent rainfall. This is affecting low lying land on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and around Derwent Water.

The forecast is for drier and brighter weather for the majority of the day, odd showers may be experienced, but will have little impact on river and lake levels.

It is advised to avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 06/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Cae Howel river gauge following recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. The road from Maesbrook to Melverley and minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood. 
Llanymynech peaked at 4.36m Wednesday morning 03/01/24. 
Some showers are forecast today, 05/01/24, but no significant rainfall is expected. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 10am on Saturday 06/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: West Somerset Streams

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message:
Most river levels in West Somerset catchments have now dropped following yesterday’s rain, however the Washford River is still high and as a result this Flood Alert remains in force. Areas most at risk include the Horner Water, Rivers Aller and Washford, and the Hawkcombe, Monksilver and Doniford Streams and tributaries. 

The forecast for the remainder of Friday and the weekend is predominantly dry with little if any rain. We expect river levels to continue dropping as a consequence through the coming days. We are monitoring the situation closely. 

Please consider local water levels and weather conditions, and avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses. Do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 

This message will be updated by 4pm on 06/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn in Shropshire
items.message:
River levels remain high on the River Severn as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land & roads adjacent to the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are White Abbey, Gravel Hill Lane Shrewsbury, Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge, Bridgnorth, property access on riverside Bridgnorth, floodplains at Hayes Basin & Leighton. 
Actual Peaks: Crew Green peaked at 6.47m & Montford peaked at 6.58m on Wednesday, 03/01/24.  Welshbridge peaked at 4.69m on Thursday morning, 04/01/24. Buildwas 6.35m Thursday evening, 04/01/24.
Bridgnorth peaked at 4.9m this morning, 05/01/24. 
Some heavy showers are forecast today, 05/01/24, but no further significant rainfall is expected. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated by 11am on Saturday 06/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Tone and Parrett Moors
items.message:
The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is currently stable at 7.57m. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m. The drain level in Currymoor is 6.88m and rising steadily. Cutts Road floods when this level is above 5.75m, and New Road when the level is above 6.18m. Both roads are currently closed. 

A band of heavy and persistent rain is forecast on Thursday afternoon and evening. The forecast for Friday is mostly dry with possible light showers. The weekend is forecast to be generally dry.
Flooding in Currymoor is expected to continue during this period. The River Tone level is currently too high to allow pumping operations, and it is forecast to rise further following today’s rain.

We continue to monitor rainfall and river levels closely, and we have staff continuously checking flood defences and pumps, and clearing weed screens. Please do not attempt to drive or walk through flood water. 

This message will be updated by 2pm on 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message:
Groundwater levels at boreholes across Cranborne Chase have risen in response to recent heavy rainfall and will continue to do so for the next few days. Flooding of roads and some properties, especially basements is expected. 
Residents should deploy any property resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers.
Driving through flood water will be especially dangerous as temperatures will drop to below freezing at times over the next week and will cause ice to form on roads. The bow wave from vehicles can flood adjacent properties and lead to icing of pavements.
Sewage systems may become overloaded. Do not lift manhole covers to alleviate local surface water flooding as this may cause toilets further downhill to surcharge.
This message will be updated on Saturday the 6th January, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lugg south of Leominster
items.message:
River levels remain high as a result of recent heavy rainfall but are now falling at the Butts Bridge & Ford Bridge river gauges and remain high but steady at the Lugwardine river gauge. Consequently, the risk of flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. 
Some showers are forecast on Friday, 05/01/24, but no further significant rainfall is expected. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated by 10am on Saturday 06/01/24, or as the situation changes.

Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas around Halesworth, Wissett, Chediston, Walpole, Huntingfield, Bramfield and Wrentham. items.description: Western Rother
items.message: The Western Rother is high and still rising downstream of Midhurst. Flooding will continue to affect properties at Lodsbridge near Selham, and may approach properties near Coultershaw Bridge too. From 12:00 on 05/01/2024 flood water will approach properties in Fittleworth. River levels are now falling in Iping and on the Lod. Flood impacts should slowly ease in Iping, Stedham, Midhurst and at Lickfold Bridge, Highstead Lane and Halfway Bridge. The river near Liss has already fallen nearer to normal, only minimal flood impacts are expected in Liss and Sheet. Very little rain is forecast for the next five days. The river should begin to fall by 14:00 on 05/01/2024 at Lodsbridge near Selham, and return nearer to normal Saturday afternoon. In Fittleworth, the river will not begin to fall until Saturday and flood impacts could remain until midweek near Fittleworth. Early actions to reduce potential impacts at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth are encouraged. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 14:00 on 06/01/2024.

items.description: Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes
items.message: The Aldingbourne Rife is high, and expected to rise a small amount Friday, following Thursday's rain. Flood impacts will continue to affect the Tesco car park on Shripney Road and around caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre, Bersted. Flood water will also affect businesses on Durban Road, Bersted. Flood water will be extensive through fields and on roads, including near Shripney Lane. In Barnham river levels are slowly falling and any flood impacts affecting Lake Lane, Barnham Road and gardens of Marshall Close, Barnham, should slowly reduce. Very little rain is forecast for the next five days. The Barnham Rife should return nearer to normal by Saturday. The Aldingbourne Rife should begin to fall by 18:00 05/01/2024 but river levels will be higher than normal until the middle of January. As a precaution, flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Barnham, if you have them. We are clearing grilles through Barnham, including at the Trading Post. Our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 14:00 06/01/2024.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Friday 5th January and over the next few days.  This is due to the natural tide locking effect.  Tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, restricts the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system.  We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning.  We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time.  Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We are closely monitoring the situation.  We will update this message on Saturday 6th January, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thame, Horsenden Stream, Chalgrove Brook

items.message: Property flooding is expected. Flood warnings are in force for the Dorchester area, for the River Thame from below Eythrope to Chiselhampton, and for the Chalgrove Brook at Chalgrove and Stadhampton. River levels are beginning to stabilise in the upper reaches of the River Thame, however, river levels are still rising along the downstream end of the River Thame as a result of recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 05/01/2024. Further showers are expected this evening and overnight. We are monitoring the situation. We expect river levels to  continue to rise slowly over the next 24 hours, particularly downstream of Thame, and levels may respond further to forecast rainfall. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message:
River levels have fallen since yesterday’s heavy rainfall event, but water levels at the Sherborne Lake gauge remain high. Consequently, a risk of flooding to low lying land and roads remains. Areas most vulnerable to flooding are the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole.
 
The forecast for today and the weekend is predominantly dry with very little if any rain.

We continue to monitor rainfall and river levels and have checked rivers for blockages in the area. Consider local conditions, weather forecasts and any flood plans. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to drive, walk or cycle through flood water. Please refer to @TravelSomerset for information on closed roads.
 
This message will be updated by 4:00pm tomorrow, Saturday 06/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Pang from East Ilsley to Pangbourne and Sulham Brook
items.message: The Flood Warning for Bucklebury has now been removed, but the alert remains in force. River levels have risen on the River Pang and the Sulham Brook in response to persistent heavy rainfall, but are now starting to fall in the upstream reaches of the Pang. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected today, especially in the Bucklebury, Tidmarsh and Sulham areas. Further scattered showers are forecast overnight and into tomorrow.  River levels remain sensitive to further rainfall. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.  This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Derwent at Buttercrambe Mill
items.message: River levels remain high on the River Derwent following recent rainfall. Flooding is expected to affect locations near the River Derwent, with low-lying land and properties expected to be most affected, particularly around Buttercrambe Mill. Levels have now peaked at Buttercrambe, but will remain high into the weekend, with further light showers forecast on Friday, followed by more settled conditions. Our incident room is open and we are closely monitoring the situation. Continue acting on your flood plan. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 8:00 PM on Friday 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Derwent

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire, York

items.message: River levels remain high but are starting to fall slowly on the lower River Derwent around Buttercrambe, Stamford Bridge, Elvington and Bubwith due to recent rainfall. Levels on Bielby Beck around Thornton Lock also remain high but are falling. Further light showers are forecast over the coming days and we expect levels to remain high. Our incident room is open and we are monitoring levels closely. We have staff checking flood defences in the area. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 04:00 AM on Saturday 06/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Avon and tributaries

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message: River levels continue to rise steadily on the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon and tributaries.  Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch.  There is further heavy rain forecast today.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and river levels closely.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.  This message will be updated by 5:00 PM on 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message:
Groundwater levels at boreholes across West Dorset have risen in response to recent heavy rainfall and will continue to do so for the next few days. Flooding of roads and some properties, especially basements is expected. 
Residents should deploy any property resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers.
Driving through flood water will be especially dangerous as temperatures will drop to below freezing at times over the next week and will cause ice to form on roads. The bow wave from vehicles can flood adjacent properties and lead to icing of pavements.
Sewage systems may become overloaded. Do not lift manhole covers to alleviate local surface water flooding as this may cause toilets further downhill to surcharge.
This message will be updated on Saturday the 6th January, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Piddle and tributaries
items.message: River levels remain high on the River Piddle following the recent rainfall and additional contributions to river flow from groundwater levels.  There is further heavy rainfall forecast for today.  Flooding is possible at tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham.  We are monitoring rainfall and river levels in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 5:00 PM on 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent in Derbyshire
items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Shardlow river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane.    

Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.  

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.   

Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.   

This message will be updated by 22:30 on 05/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Bure, Spixworth Beck and surrounding Becks
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Friday 5th January 2024.  We are currently seeing higher river levels than normal in response to recent rainfall.  The forecast is for predominantly dry conditions for the next few days with some isolated showers possible.  Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message tomorrow, Saturday 6th January 2024.

items.description: Tern and Perry catchments

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels remain high but are steady on the rivers Tern and Perry, following recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington. 
Some showers are forecast today, 05/01/24, but no further significant rainfall is expected. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated by 10am on Saturday 06/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ouse at York - riverside properties
items.message: River levels at the York Viking Recorder are falling slowly but remain high due to recent rainfall associated with Storm Henk. Flooding continues to affect locations near the River Ouse in York, particularly around properties and land from Scarborough Bridge to Millennium Bridge and King's Staith. Levels are expected to remain high for the next few days but to continue falling. Our incident room remains open and we are closely monitoring the situation. Riverside floodgates remain closed and the Foss Barrier is operational. Please put your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 5:30PM on Friday 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message:
River and lake levels remain high on the Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster due to recent rainfall. Whilst river and lake levels continue to recede, Windermere Lake remains high and will continue to do so throughout today.

The forecast is for drier and brighter weather for the majority of the day, odd showers may be experienced, but will have little impact on river and lake levels.

Flooding may affect low lying land, particularly around Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 06/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Leach from Northleach to Mill Lane near Lechlade
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but steady on the River Leach following recent rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 05/01/2024, especially in the Lechlade area.  This morning is forecast to be mainly dry, followed by further showers this evening and overnight which have the potential to be heavy at times. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days and will remain sensitive to further rainfall. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Waveney from Diss and the River Dove to Ellingham, including Bungay
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Friday 5th January 2024.  The River Waveney is rising steadily in response to the recent rainfall.  Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas around Diss, Eye, Harleston and Bungay.  The forecast is for predominantly dry conditions for the next few days with some isolated showers possible.  Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We are monitoring the situation closely.  We will update this message tomorrow, Saturday 6th January.

items.description: Eastern Yar
items.message: Water levels in the Eastern Yar remain high. Levels at Alverstone have stabilised. Levels at Sandown are rising and will continue to rise until 17:00 this evening (05/01/2024). Currently, there is extensive out of bank flooding through the Yar Valley, with roads, cycle tracks, and footpaths being impassable. Moreton Common and Golf Links Road are flooded. Fort Holiday Park and Sandown sewage works will flood as ditches struggle to drain to the river. Impacts are also expected at Nicholas Close, Brading. This is following yesterday's rain as 27mm was recorded at Wroxhall, which is a significant amount of rain. This is in addition to the prolonged rainfall over the last few months. Bembridge sluice is operating normally. Please ensure any products used to protect gardens and property from flooding are operating. Flood warnings remain in force for the Upper and Lower Eastern Yar. The next five days are forecast to be mainly dry. This Flood Alert will be updated by 12:00 on 06/01/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message: Groundwater levels are high and rising at our observation borehole in Draycot Foliat in the Upper Og Valley in response to recent rainfall across the area. Groundwater levels are higher than normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may now be affected by flooding from groundwater. The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. Levels at this site are sensitive to individual rainfall events and will likely rise again due to the recent heavy rainfall. Low-lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 12/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Chertsey Bourne

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels on the Chertsey Bourne remain high due to recent rainfall and are currently stable. Flooding of low lying land is expected to continue.   The forecast for today (05/01/24) is for mostly dry conditions with the chance of some light showers tonight.  Levels will remain high over the next 24 hours, but will slowly start to fall.                                                                                                                      Flood Warnings remain in force for the Chertsey Bourne at Thorpe Green, and the Chertsey Bourne at Chertsey

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/01/24, or as the situation changes.

This morning is forecast to be mainly dry, followed by further showers this evening and overnight which have the potential to be heavy at times. We are monitoring the situation.  River levels remain sensitive to further rainfall. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Flintshire, Shropshire, Wrexham

items.message: Water levels are still high on the River Dee and flooding of land is still possible, however, the river is now slowly, but steadily, falling and after some showers today (Friday 5th January) there is no more rain forecast for the next few days at least so we expect the river to continue to fall.  However, levels are likely to remain above the Flood Alert threshold until Wednesday 10th January.  We will continue to monitor the situation and update this message on Monday 8th January before 12 noon or earlier if the situation changes.

items.message: The risk of flooding from the East and West Glen Rivers have now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

items.description: Lower River Nidd catchment

items.description: Mid Bristol Avon area

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
Further rainfall is forecast throughout today which will cause river levels to rise further. Flood warnings have been issued for Bristol Avon at Bradford on Avon and from Melksham to Bathford (not including Bradford on Avon). River levels are expected to remain high into Wednesday 3rd January 2024. 

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. 

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 

This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 03/01/2024 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is stable at 8.92m. The Huish Episcopi drain level is 8.47m and rising. Flooding will affect the road between Muchelney and Langport if this level exceeds 7.30m, the Muchelney to Long Load road above 7.86m, the Thorney road above 7.93m, and the Muchelney to Drayton road above 8.80m. Property flooding is expected at levels above 8.35m. 

The forecast for Friday and the weekend is predominantly dry with very little if any rain. However we are currently unable to pump at stations upstream of Langport due to very high river levels. Pumping operations and use of the Parrett Relief Channel will start as soon as river levels allow. We are monitoring the situation closely and staff are checking flood defences and pumps. 

Please do not attempt to drive or walk through flood water, and refer to @TravelSomerset for local road closures. This message will be updated by 4pm on 06/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Curry Moor and Hay Moor
items.message:
The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is currently 7.60m and stable. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m. The drain level in Currymoor is 7.52m and rising slowly. Cutts Road floods when this level is above 5.75m, and New Road when the level is above 6.18m. Both roads are currently closed.
Water from Currymoor is now running over the spillways at Athelney and Lyng Cutting. We are monitoring this closely and have pumps ready at Northmoor and Saltmoor pumping stations.
The forecast is for dry, cold weather over the next week. 
Flooding in Currymoor is expected to continue during this period. The River Tone level is currently too high to allow pumping operations, and is likely to remain high in the coming days as ground water comes down from the upper catchment, which is saturated.
We continue to monitor rainfall and river levels closely, and we have staff checking flood defences and pumps. Please do not attempt to drive or walk through flood water. This message will be updated by 2pm on 06/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Derwent at Stamford Bridge - The Weir Caravan Park and Kexby Bridge

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message: River levels remain high but starting to fall on the River Derwent due to recent rainfall. Flooding is expected to affect locations near the River Derwent, with low-lying land and properties expected to be most affected, particularly around the Weir Caravan Park at Stamford Bridge and properties at Kexby Bridge. Levels are now peaking in the Upper Derwent catchment, but will remain high into the weekend, with further light showers forecast in the next few days. Our incident room is open and we are closely monitoring the situation. Consider putting your flood plan into action. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 08:00 PM on Friday 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Yeo and Parrett, downstream of Yeovil to Steart

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Parrett, River Yeo, Cary, Sowy, Kings Sedgemoor Drain

items.message:
River levels remain high in the middle and lower reaches of the River Parrett and River Yeo, following yesterday’s rain.

Areas most at risk of flooding today include the Ilchester to Yeovilton road at the end of the runway, the Mudford to Limington road and the road at the south end of Westover Trading Estate. Properties at Westover Trading Estate at Langport are at risk. Bankfull conditions are forecast at Ilchester and water will reach the bottom of the ringbanks at Ilchester Meads and Ilchester.

The forecast for Friday and the weekend is predominantly dry with very little if any rain. The risk of flooding is reducing. We will continue to monitor levels closely, and our incident response staff are checking flood defences.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and remain aware of local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 4 PM on 06/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Friday 5th January and over the next few days. This is due to the natural tide locking effect. Tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, restricts the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay.  We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation.  We will update this message on Saturday 6th January, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hambledon
items.message: In Hambledon, groundwater levels are high but currently slowly falling. However, in the last 7 days, more than half a month’s rain (56mm) has been recorded at Worlds End. Groundwater levels in Hambledon are expected to begin rising again from tomorrow (04/01/2023). Properties along West and East Street are experiencing ongoing cellar flooding. Groundwater is inundating the sewerage system. Fareham Road is flooded and the football pitch is being affected by a mixture of groundwater and sewerage. The weather forecast for the next five days is for relatively small amounts of rain. However, there is a possibility that heavy rain (45mm) could be recorded in Hampshire on Thursday (04/01/2024). Groundwater levels in Hambledon are expected to rise for at least the next 7 days. If heavy rain affects the area, levels could rise very quickly. Further cellar flooding is expected during this time. We are liaising with Hambledon Flood Action Group. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 10/01/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle
items.message: In Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle, groundwater levels remain high. In the last 7 days, more than half a month’s rain (45mm) has been recorded at Walderton. The Idsworth and Chalton Lavants are both flowing. Minor road flooding impacts are expected throughout the valley. Pumps which prevent water from entering property will be required for a small number of properties. Surface water flooding may occur during heavier rain events. The weather forecast for the next five days is for relatively small amounts of rain. However, there is a possibility that heavy rain (45mm) could be recorded in Hampshire on Thursday (04/01/2024). Groundwater levels are expected to rise for at least 7 days. Further road and cellar flooding is expected during this time, particularly if heavy rain affects the valley. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 10/01/2024.

items.description: Lower River Medway
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels remain high on the Medway following heavy rainfall on Monday this week. Further isolated showers are forecast throughout Friday 5th January. Areas most at risk include low lying land and towpaths along the Medway, between Teston and Allington Lock, including underpasses at Maidstone Town Centre. Flooding of these areas is likely to continue until Saturday 6th January. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We expect river levels to remain high throughout the day. Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. This message will be updated by 9pm on Friday 5th January, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Maun in Nottinghamshire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message:
Groundwater levels are rising in response to recent rainfall across the area and have continued rising at our observation borehole in Longacre in the Lambourn Valley. Groundwater levels are higher than normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater.
The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. Low-lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.
We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 12/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Minor watercourses of the South Forty Foot Drain
items.message: Heavy rainfall has fallen onto saturated ground over the past few days in the South Forty Foot Drain catchment area. This has caused river levels to rise, leading to flooding of low lying land and roads close to rivers. We expect rivers to remain high throughout the next few days. Flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on Floodline by 16:00 on 06/01/2024, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Witham in South Kesteven
items.message: The risk of flooding from the River Witham in South Kesteven has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

items.description: Witham in North Kesteven

This has caused river levels to rise, leading to flooding of low lying land and roads close to rivers. No further significant rainfall is forecast however we expect rivers to remain high throughout the next few days.  Flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on Floodline by 16:00 on 06/01/2024, or before if the situation changes.

 We are closely monitoring the situation.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: Flooding is possible this afternoon, Thursday 04/01/24. Heavy rain has fallen across Devon, and is expected to continue until early Friday morning. This means that river levels will remain high for the next couple of days as the catchments are already very wet. Levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. items.message:
River levels are rising on the River Parrett this evening due to heavy rainfall earlier today. Flooding is expected at the River Parrett downstream of Gawbridge, the A356 at Chiselborough, the Norton Sub Hamdon to Stratton road and Parrett Works near Martock from 8 PM this evening and overnight.

Further rainfall is forecast over the next few hours, but this is expected to clear the area by midnight. The river level at the Chiselborough gauge is forecast to begin falling after this time.

The forecast for Friday is mostly dry with possible light showers, and the weekend is forecast to be generally dry. We continue to monitor the situation closely, and have had incident response staff out checking rivers in the area for blockages.

Consider activating any property flood protection products you may have, and start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 4 PM on 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Combe Haven
items.message: The Combe Haven is high in Bulverhythe, following persistent rain since the New Year and intense rain Thursday. Flooding will continue to affect Bulverhythe Recreation Ground until next week. In Crowhurst, river levels are already falling, minor impacts should continue to ease, with small amounts of water remaining in fields, on roads and in gardens. Very little rain is forecast for the next five days. The river should continue falling in Crowhurst. In Bulverhythe, river levels should slowly fall from Saturday afternoon. However, in Bulverhythe, the river will still remain higher than normal for most of next week. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Crowhurst, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 15:00 06/01/2024

Flood water will remain in fields and gardens. Very little rain is forecast for the next five days. The river should return nearer to normal by Saturday 06/01/2024. Some roads, including the Coolham road at Slaughter Bridge, may still be affected by flood water, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 14:00 06/01/2024

items.description: Cuckmere River
items.message: The Cuckmere River through Alfriston is high and rising, following Thursday's rain. On Friday, flooding will affect North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. Access along Litlington Road may be restricted by flood water. Flood water will be extensive in fields and on roads. The Bull River through Hellingly is high, but now slowly falling. Flood impacts should ease on Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. The Cuckmere River through Hellingly has already fallen significantly, only minor flood impacts are expected on Mill Lane, Hellingly. Very little rain is forecast for the next five days. The river should begin to fall in Alfriston by 16:00 05/01/2024, but flood impacts could remain until Monday. In Hellingly flood impacts should be minimal Saturday. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding, including Mill Lane and Church Road Hellingly and North Street Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 15:00 06/01/2024.

items.description: Upper Ouse
items.message: The River Ouse is high and rising near Barcombe, following Thursday's rain. Flooding will continue to affect the Anchor Inn near Barcombe. Property flooding could occur in Barcombe Mills from 12:00 05/01/2024. Flood water will remain close to Freshfield Mill Farm, Freshmill and Millers Cottages on Sloop Lane. Flood water will continue to affect roads at Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge. Barcombe Mills road will be impassable. Nearer Ardingly, the River Ouse is already falling. Flood impacts should reduce through Friday, near Dean's Water Mill on the B2028 near Lindfield and the gardens of Shell Brook cottages, Ardingly. Very little rain is forecast for the next five days. The river should begin to fall in Barcombe by 16:00 05/01/2024, but flood impacts could remain until the river falls nearer to normal Saturday. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Barcombe Mills road. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 15:00 06/01/2024.

items.description: Barcombe Mills
items.message: The River Ouse is high and rising following Thursday's rain. Flooding will continue to affect the Anchor Inn. Property flooding could occur in Barcombe Mills from 12:00 05/01/2024. Flooding will remain extensive through fields, on roads and in gardens. Barcombe Mills road is likely to be impassable. Very little rain is forecast for the next five days. The river should begin to fall by 16:00 05/01/2024, but flood impacts could remain until the river falls nearer to normal by Saturday afternoon. Some roads may be impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Barcombe Mills Road. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Barcombe, if you have them. We are operating our structures in Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 15:00 06/01/2024.

items.description: North Holderness
items.message: Levels are high on Barmston Drain due to heavy rainfall and the effect of the tide. Areas most at risk include North Holderness including Skipsea, Hornsea and Lissett. Further showers are expected over the next couple of days, with drier more settled weather expected from Sunday into next week. We expect river levels to remain high for several days. Our incident room is open and we are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 07:30 PM on Friday 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.

Flooding is affecting areas in Dorchester, West Stafford, Bockhampton, Lewell, Tincleton, Pallington, Waddock, Moreton, Wool and East Stoke from 07:00 AM on 05/01/2024.

items.message: River levels are rising in response to last night’s rainfall. Flooding is expected on the Hundred Foot (Ouse) Washes for several days. This information is correct as of 16:00 on 05/01/24. The causeway at Sutton Gault currently has 92cm of water on the road. The causeway at Welney currently has 70cm of water on the road. The causeway at Earith currently has 17cm of water on the road. The Environment Agency are liaising with Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the road. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. Further rainfall is expected today. Floodwater is travelling down the River Great Ouse towards the Ouse Washes which will keep levels high for several days. Avoid driving through floodwater and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 8am tomorrow, 06/01/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Dean, Singleton, Charlton, East Dean and Chilgrove
items.message: Above average rainfall has been measured between October and December 2023. Groundwater is high, close to the surface and rising at the East Dean borehole. Minor groundwater flood impacts are expected to continue, with water flowing on roads, in basements or under floorboards, and affecting the ability of the sewage network to operate in East Dean, Charlton, Singleton and West Dean. Water could also affect the B2141 Chilgrove road. Tuesday afternoon and Wednesday should see very little rainfall, but another 20-30mm of rain could occur Thursday afternoon 04/01/2024. Groundwater at all boreholes could rise a small amount through to next week 08/01/2024. Flood impacts are expected to remain until the middle of January, and potentially longer, or affecting more people if wet weather continues. Groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any additional rainfall over winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 06/01/2024

We will continue to monitor the river and weather forecast information. This message will be updated by 12:00 on 06/01/2024.

items.description: Minor Watercourses from Heighington to Dunston
items.message: Heavy rainfall has fallen onto saturated ground over the past few days in the Heighington to Dunston catchment area. This has caused river levels to rise, leading to flooding of low lying land and roads close to rivers. We expect rivers to remain high throughout the next few days. Flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties is possible and therefore flood warnings have been issued.  We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on Floodline by 16:00 on 06/01/2024, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Danes Stream
items.message: Water levels in the Danes Stream remain high, but are stable, following yesterday’s rain when 25 mm was recorded at Stem Lane. This is a significant amount of rain in a short period of time. This is in addition to the prolonged rainfall over the last few months. The water level in the village remains high, and there is some footpath flooding. Gardens at Milford-on-Sea High Street may also be affected. Keep away from the riverside footpaths in Milford-on-Sea, especially at Milford Bridge opposite Lucerne Road. If footpaths are flooded, it will be difficult to see where the edge of the main river channel is. These flooding impacts will continue throughout today (05/01/2024) and tomorrow (06/01/2024). The weather is now fairly dry for the next 5 days. We expect water levels to start to fall today (05/01/2024), and levels will continue to fall over the next few days. Milford Dam is operating correctly. We will continue to monitor the river and weather forecast information. This message will be updated by 12:00 on 06/01/2024.

items.description: River Ebble and tributaries
items.message: River levels remain high at the Ebbesbourne Wake river gauge on the River Ebble due to the rainfall over recent days falling on catchments that are already saturated. High groundwater levels continue to add further to river flow. There is a possibility of flooding at locations near the River Ebble, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Alvediston and Nunton. TFurther heavy rainfall is expected this afternoon. River levels are expected to remain high overnight and into tomorrow. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, consider installing property flood resilience equipment, plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to your local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 5:00 PM on 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes

items.description: River Piddle from Alton Pancras to Wareham
items.message:
River levels are rising steadily on the River Piddle due to rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Piddle, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Alton Pancras, Piddletrenthide, Piddlehinton, Druce, Puddletown, Athelhampton, Affpuddle, Briantspuddle, Throop and Wareham including Purbeck View Park.
Throop and Wareham including Purbeck View Park from 04:30 PM on 04/01/2024.
Further rainfall is forecast throughout the afternoon.
River levels are remaining high.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your surroundings.
This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 04/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors, low lying properties around Muchelney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is very high but stable at 8.92m. The Huish Episcopi drain level is 8.47m and rising. Flooding will affect the road between Muchelney and Langport if this level exceeds 7.30m, the Muchelney to Long Load road above 7.86m, the Thorney road above 7.93m, and the Muchelney to Drayton road above 8.80m. Property flooding is expected at drain levels above 8.35m. 

The forecast for Friday and the weekend is predominantly dry with very little if any rain. We are currently unable to pump at stations upstream of Langport due to the very high river levels. Pumping operations and use of the Parrett Relief Channel will start as soon as river levels allow. We are monitoring the situation closely and staff are checking flood defences and pumps. 

Please do not attempt to drive or walk through flood water, and refer to @TravelSomerset for local road closures. This message will be updated by 4pm on 06/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent at Carlton on Trent including Beck Cottage
items.message:
"River levels are rising at the Carlton-On-Trent river gauge as a result of Storm Henk.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are access roads and properties in Girton. If levels continue to rise, the A1133 and High Street may flood, which could isolate the village.
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until Sunday 07/01/2024.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please follow advice from emergency services and avoid contact with flood water.  If you have been flooded, please contact your insurance provider.
This message will be updated by 18:00 on 06/01/23, or as the situation changes."

items.description: Brockenhurst and Boldre on the River Lymington
items.message: Water levels in the Lymington River are now falling following yesterday’s rain when 30 mm was recorded at Brockenhurst. This is a significant amount of rain in a short period of time. This is in addition to the prolonged rainfall over the last few months. The weather is now fairly dry for the next 5 days. We expect water levels to continue to fall over the next few days. No further property flooding is expected, but the river level will remain higher than normal for the next few days. A Flood Alert for the Lymington River remains in force. We will continue to monitor the river and weather forecast information.

items.description: River Trent at Collingham
items.message:
"River levels are rising at the Torksey river gauge as a result of Storm Henk.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are Collingham.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until Sunday 07/01/2024.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please follow advice from emergency services and avoid contact with flood water.  If you have been flooded, please contact your insurance provider.
This message will be updated by 18:00 on 06/01/23, or as the situation changes."

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
River levels are rising steadily on the Lower Hampshire Avon due to heavy rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Hampshire Avon, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Bickerley, Ringwood and the B3347 from Christchurch to Stony Lane in Christchurch.
Flooding is affecting Bickerley, Ringwood and the B3347 from Christchurch to Stony Lane in Christchurch from 09:00 PM on 04/01/2024.
No further significant rainfall is forecast.
River levels are forecast to rise, but the risk of flooding to properties remains.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent at Newark Tolney Lane and Riverside Marinas
items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Farndon river gauge as a result of Storm Henk. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are Tolney Lane Caravan Site and riverside marinas in Newark.
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high until Saturday 06/01/2024.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please follow advice from emergency services and avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow, 06/01/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ouse at Naburn Lock
items.message: River levels at the York Viking Recorder and Naburn weir are falling slowly but remain high due to recent rainfall associated with Storm Henk. Flooding continues to affect locations near the River Ouse, particularly around Naburn Lock buildings and Lock cottages. Levels are expected to remain high for a few days but to continue falling. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Our incident room is open and we are closely monitoring the situation. We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities. Please put your flood plan into action. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 5:30PM on Friday 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Holderness
items.message: Levels remain high on the Skeffling Drain and Winestead Drain due to recent heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk include the South East Holderness area including Winestead, Patrington and Kilnsea. Further showers are forecast over the next few days, before drier, more settled weather arrives on Sunday and into next week. Levels are high at the Winestead Booster Pumping stations and Skeffling Pumping Station. Our incident rooms are open, we are closely monitoring the situation and managing pumping in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 08:30 PM on Friday 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle River Roding
items.message:
River levels remain high on the Roding due to yesterday's heavy rainfall.
Flooding may continue to affect locations near the Roding, with low lying land most affected, particularly around Hillmans Cottages; Ongar Road; Roding Road; Roding Lane.
Rainfall is expected to ease through today and over the weekend, but river levels could remain high over the coming days.
River levels are high but steady, and the risk of flooding to low-lying land remains.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated on 06/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Hooke
items.message:
Groundwater levels have risen in response to recent heavy rainfall and will continue to do so for the next few days. Flooding of roads and some properties, especially basements is expected. 
Residents should deploy any property resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers.
Driving through flood water will be especially dangerous as temperatures will drop to below freezing at times over the next week. The bow wave from vehicles can flood adjacent properties and lead to icing of pavements.
Sewage systems may become overloaded. Do not lift manhole covers to alleviate local surface water flooding as this may cause toilets further downhill to surcharge.
This message will be updated on Saturday the 6th January, or as the situation changes.

items.message:

Sewage systems may become overloaded. Do not lift manhole covers to alleviate local surface water flooding as this may cause toilets further downhill to surcharge.
This message will be updated on Saturday the 6th January, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Ems
items.message: The River Ems is high, but stable, following Thursday's rain. Minor flood impacts could continue to affect fields, Brook Meadows, rural roads and gardens in Westbourne and Emsworth. However, very little rain is forecast for the next five days. The river is expected to remain fairly stable over the coming week, but could rise a couple of centimetres from the present level, because groundwater upstream is rising. River levels should begin to slow by 10/01/2024, but will be higher than normal throughout January. As a precaution, flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Westbourne and Emsworth, if you have them. We are operating our structure at Constant Springs and clearing grilles to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will re issue this message if the risk of property flooding increases.

items.description: Upper Meon
items.message: Water levels in the River Meon are now generally falling, following yesterday’s rain when 35 mm was recorded at Warnford. This is a significant amount of rain in a short period of time. This is in addition to the prolonged rainfall over the last few months. We expect water levels to continue to generally fall over the next few days. The weather is now fairly dry for the next 5 days. There will continue to be flooding on land throughout the Meon valley. We will continue to monitor the river and weather forecast information. Avoid walking or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 12:00 on 06/01/2023.

items.description: Upper River Colne and Radlett Brook
items.message:
River levels are high on the Colne and Mimmshall Brook, due to heavy rainfall. The forecast is now improving with little further rain forecast. River levels will begin to fall in most locations but remain high in others, particularly around London Colney.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Colne and Mimmshall Brook today, Friday 5th January. Low lying land will be most affected, particularly around Waterside, Lowbell Lane, London Colney, and Warrengate Road.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated this evening on Friday 5th January, or as the situation changes.

items.message:

The forecast is now improving and we expect river levels to continue to drop through out the day. 
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

items.description: Lower Meon
items.message: Water levels in the River Meon at Titchfield are slowly falling following yesterday’s rain, when 34 mm was recorded at Warnford. This is a significant amount of rain in a short period of time. This is in addition to the prolonged rainfall over the last few months. The weather is now fairly dry for the next 5 days. We expect water levels to continue to fall slowly over the next few days. The river level will remain higher than normal, and there will continue to be flooding on land throughout the Meon valley. Avoid walking or driving through flood water. We will continue to monitor the river and weather forecast information. This message will be updated by 16:00 on 06/01/2024.

items.description: River Wylye and tributaries
items.message: River levels remain high on the River Wylye at South Newton due to recent rainfall.  Areas most at risk include tributaries between Norton Ferris and Wilton.  There is further heavy rain forecast today.  We are monitoring rainfall and river levels in the area.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 5:00 PM on 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Whitwell, Wroxall, Langbridge, Alverstone on the Eastern Yar
items.message: Water levels in the Eastern Yar remain high. Levels at Alverstone have stabilised, and will begin to fall slowly this morning (05/01/2024). Currently, there is extensive out of bank flooding through the Yar Valley, with roads, cycle tracks, and footpaths being impassable. This is following yesterday's rain as 27mm was recorded at Wroxhall, which is a significant amount of rain in a short period of time, and is about a third of the normal monthly average rainfall. This is in addition to the prolonged rainfall which has been affecting the area over the last few months. We continue to monitor the forecast and will ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Please ensure any products used to protect gardens and property from flooding are operating. The next five days are forecast to be mainly dry. This Flood Warning will be updated by 12:00 on 06/01/2024.

items.description: The Rivers Wid and Can
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today Friday 5th January 2024. River levels are currently high as the river responds to overnight rainfall.  River levels will likely continue to rise this morning. The forecast is for showers to get more scattered and less intense as we move into drier weather over the weekend.  Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation closely.  We will update this message tomorrow, Saturday 6th January.

items.description: The Rattlesden River and River Gipping, through and including Stowmarket and Needham Market
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Friday 5th January 2024.  The River Gipping is rising steadily in response to the overnight rainfall.  The forecast is for predominantly dry conditions for the next few days.  Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message tomorrow Saturday 6th January 2024.

items.description: River Dikler from Condicote to Little Rissington
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high on the River Dikler following recent rain, but are now falling. The risk of flooding of low lying land and roads remains, especially in areas close to Bourton on the Water. This morning is forecast to be mainly dry, followed by further showers this evening and overnight which have the potential to be heavy at times. We expect river levels to continue falling but will remain sensitive to further rainfall. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Ginge Brook
items.message: The Flood Warning for Steventon has now been removed. River levels are high, but are now falling, on the Ginge Brook following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 05/01/2024, especially in the Steventon area. Further scattered showers are forecast overnight and into tomorrow. We are monitoring the situation. River levels will remain high over the coming days, and may rise again in response to forecast rainfall. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Bourn Brook in Cambridgeshire
items.message: River levels are high, but steady following last night’s heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk are around Bourn Brook, from Caxton to Comberton. Further light rainfall is expected over the next 12 hours which will keep river levels high. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate.  We will update this message by 5pm today, 05/01/2024.

items.description: Cottenham Lode in Cambridgeshire
items.message: River levels are rising steadily in response to heavy rainfall overnight. Areas most at risk are around Cottenham Lode including Oakington Brook, Wash Pit Brook and Beck Brook. We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 5pm today, 05/01/2024.
