items.message: River levels are rising steadily in response to heavy rainfall overnight. Areas most at risk are around the River Great Ouse from Wyboston to the south of Brampton, including Duloe Brook, Hen Brook and Fox Brook. Further light rainfall is expected over the next 12 hours which will keep river levels high. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate.  We will update this message by 5pm today, 05/01/2024.

items.description: River Stour in South Warwickshire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.    
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively monitoring river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued.

items.description: Osbaldwick Beck and Tanghall Beck
items.message: This alert has been removed due to levels falling back below levels of concern. We continue to monitor the forecast and will reissue this alert if necessary.

items.description: Hellingly and Horsebridge
items.message: The Cuckmere and Bull Rivers are now falling, following Thursday's rain. Flood impacts should slowly ease on Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. River levels are already significantly lower on the Cuckmere, so only minor flood impacts are expected on Mill Lane, Hellingly and Grove Hill near Grovebridge Farm. Flood water will likely remain extensive in fields and on roads. A Flood Alert remains in force to describe minor flood impacts. Very little rain is forecast for the next five days. The rivers should continue falling Friday and return nearer to normal by Saturday 06/01/2024. Some roads including Mill Road and Church Road may still be affected by flood water. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re issue this Flood Warning if the risk of property flooding increases.

items.description: Middle River Aire catchment
items.message: River levels on the River Aire between Keighley and Castleford have now fallen below our flood risk thresholds and there is no longer a threat of flooding. However, levels in Allerton Ings remain high but will drain away slowly. There is no further rain forecast over the coming days. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: Lower River Aire catchment
items.message: River levels have fallen below our flood risk thresholds in the Lower River Aire catchment following persistent rainfall earlier in the week, however levels remain high in washland areas throughout the Lower Aire catchment. Therefore, this Flood Alert remains in force. We are not expecting any further significant rainfall over the coming days, therefore levels of rivers and washlands should continue to fall. We will continue to monitor rainfall and river levels closely and our operational staff will be out checking our flood defences and that washland areas are draining properly. Water will remain in washlands and on low lying land over the coming days. Please take care near waterlogged land and flooded fields and use alternative routes until the water has receded. Do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 20:30 on 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Loddon
items.message:
River levels remain high on the River Loddon as a result of a period of sustained rain.  Flooding of low lying land is expected to continue. The forecast for today (05/01/24) is for mostly dry conditions with the chance of some light showers tonight.  Levels will continue to slowly rise over the next 24 hours.                                                                                                                              

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in upper River Ems Valley
items.message: Above average rainfall has been measured between October and December 2023. Groundwater is high and close to the surface, and following Monday and Tuesday's rain is now slowly rising again at the Compton borehole. Tuesday afternoon and Wednesday should see very little rainfall, but another 20-30mm of rain could occur Thursday afternoon 04/01/2024. Minor groundwater flood impacts will likely continue or return this week, with springs affecting fields, the village green Stoughton, and rural roads including Stoughton main road, the road from East Marden and also between Cooks Lane and The Barley Mow, and the B2146 near Woodlands Lane, in Walderton. Particularly during or after rain. Groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any rainfall over winter. Colder weather, with less rain could be possible next week, which could allow groundwater to stabilise and potentially fall. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 06/01/2024

items.description: River Kennet from Thatcham down to Reading
items.message: Property flooding is expected. A flood warning is in force for the Theale and Burghfield area. River levels are rising on the lower River Kennet following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land, roads and property is expected to continue today, especially in the Theale area. This morning is forecast to be mainly dry, followed by further showers this evening and overnight which have the potential to be heavy at times. River levels will remain high over the next few days and will remain sensitive to further rainfall. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and be aware of flood water remaining on the floodplain. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Wharfe
items.message: River levels are falling slowly but remain high on the Wharfe downstream of Tadcaster and at Cawood as a result of recent rainfall associated with Storm Henk. Areas most at risk include the tidal River Wharfe downstream of Tadcaster around Ulleskelf and Ryther and up to the confluence with the River Ouse. Levels are expected to remain high for the next few days but to continue falling. Our incident response staff have closed flood gates and checked defences in the area. We are managing pumping in the area and the flood warning at Ryther remains in force. Our incident room is open and we continue to monitor levels closely. Plan driving routes to avoid roads between Tadcaster and Cawood that are affected by flooding. This message will be updated by 05:30 PM on Friday 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Selby to Faxfleet

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message: River levels remain high on the Tidal River Ouse due to heavy rainfall associated with Storm Henk. Areas most at risk include the tidal foreshore and agricultural land adjacent to the river from the A63 near Selby to the Yokefleet, Blacktoft and Faxfleet areas. Further light rainfall is forecast on Friday, and river levels are still high upstream, but levels are expected to fall slowly over the coming days. Low lying fields and roads adjacent to watercourses and washlands are likely to have water remaining on them for a number of days even as river levels fall. Our incident room is open and we will continue to monitor the river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8PM on Friday 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes

items.description: Tidal River Aire catchment

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message: River levels have fallen below our flood risk thresholds in the Lower River Aire catchment following persistent rainfall earlier in the week, however levels remain high in washland areas throughout the Lower Aire catchment. Therefore, this Flood Alert remains in force. We are not expecting any further significant rainfall over the coming days, therefore levels of rivers and washlands should continue to fall. We will continue to monitor rainfall and river levels closely and our operational staff will be out checking our flood defences and that washland areas are draining properly. Water will remain in washlands and on low lying land over the coming days. Please take care near waterlogged land and flooded fields and use alternative routes until the water has receded. Do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 20:30 on 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Mardyke to the River Thames at Purfleet
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely this morning Friday 5th January 2024. River levels are currently high as the river responds to current rainfall. River levels are likely to continue to rise this morning in response to further rain, but then fall quickly today. The forecast is for showers to get more scattered and less intense as we move into more settled weather. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation closely. We will update this message tomorrow, Saturday 6th January.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Patcham
items.message: Groundwater is high, close to the surface, and rising. 30mm of rain fell in only a few hours Thursday, which is a lot in a short period of time. Minor groundwater flood impacts are now expected from 06/01/2024. Water could begin to appear in a small number of basements. Previous events suggest impacts may initially affect Old London Road, Patcham and Peacock Lane, Withdean. Very little rain is forecast Friday through to next week. Groundwater could continue rising until 10/01/2024 at Ladies Mile borehole, and a few days after in Patcham village centre. Flood impacts should begin to reduce from the middle of January. However, groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any additional rainfall over winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We will continue to monitor levels and forecasts and liaise with Brighton and Hove City Council. We will update this message by 18:00 on 10/01/2024.

items.description: River Derwent at Church Wilne and Wilne Lane
items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low-lying land. Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses. Avoid contact with Flood water.

items.description: Upper Roding
items.message:
Although there may be some further showers today, the forecast is now improving and the worst of the rain has passed.
Flooding is forecast to continue to affect locations near the Roding, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Broad Bridge Cottages, Bridge House, Mill Lane, and Hallsford Bridge Industrial Estate. 
River levels are forecast to remain high at the High Ongar and Shonks Mill Bridge gauges throughout the day. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 
This message will be updated on the evening of Friday 5th January, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Low Barlings and the Short Ferry area

floodArea.riverOrSea: Barlings Eau, Stainfield Beck, Marsh Drain

items.message: Heavy rain over the past week in the River Witham catchment has fallen onto already saturated ground. This caused the Barlings Eau to rise. Low lying areas near to the rivers are flooded. No significant further rainfall is forecast, however we expect the river levels to remain high for the next few days. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings. Please avoid contact with flood water. Our staff are out in the area to check the flood defences, clear blockages, and assist the emergency services and council. We will be closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 16:00 on 6th January, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: River levels remain high in the Peterborough area following persistent rainfall. During periods of high tide the river Nene will be unable to discharge into the sea, resulting in tide lock conditions. Whilst this flood warning remains in force, the local authority will close North Bank Road. We expect this flood warning to remain in force for the next few days. Diversionary routes will be in place and further updates will be available through the local media. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 16:00 on 6th January, or before, if the situation changes.

items.description: B1040 Thorney to Whittlesey Road to the South of the River Nene
items.message: Heavy rain has fallen onto already saturated ground over the last few days. This has caused the River Nene to rise and will remain high for the next few days. The Whittlesey Wash flood storage reservoir is being operated to protect nearby communities from flooding. The rising levels in the Wash will result in flooding of the B1040 road. Whilst the Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority may close the B1040 for safety reasons. We expect the Flood Warning to be in force for the next few days. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media. We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 16:00 on 6th January, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Colne and Frays River

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hertfordshire, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels are remaining high on the Colne, Frays, Wraysbury, and Poyle Channel, due to recent heavy rainfall. 
Flooding is forecast to continue to affect locations near the Colne, Frays, Wraysbury, and Poyle Channel, with low lying land most affected, particularly around Longford. 
River levels are high but stable. No further significant rainfall is expected. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 
This message will be updated this evening, Friday 5th January, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Arun
items.message: The River Arun is high, and rising following Thursday's rain. Flood water will continue to be extensive through fields and gardens and close to properties on Lower Street and Swan Corner, Pulborough, near to Swan Bridge and Bridge Cottages, Greatham. Flood water could affect properties in Pulborough from 14:00 Friday 05/01/2024. After each high tide, water will be close to the tops of the banks and in fields near Houghton Bridge, Amberley. With tides low and falling, flood water is only expected to affect fields in Arundel. Very little rain is forecast for the next five days. The river should begin to fall by 12:00 Saturday 06/01/2024, but flood impacts could remain into the start of next week. River levels will be slow to fall, the river could still be higher than normal by mid January. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Pulborough, Amberley and Arundel, if you have them. Our pumps in Pulborough are running to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 18:00 06/01/2024

items.description: River Cherwell from Charwelton to just above Upper Heyford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Highfurlong Brook, Ashby Brook, Culworth Brook, Hanwell Brook, Chacombe Brook, Marston Brook, Thenford Brook, Farthinghoe Brook, Charlton Brook, River Swere, Deddington Brook

items.message: Property flooding is expected. A flood warning is in force for the Kings Sutton area. River levels are high on the River Cherwell following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Banbury and Kings Sutton areas. This morning is forecast to be mainly dry, followed by further showers this evening and overnight which have the potential to be heavy at times. River levels have begun to stabilise at Banbury and are falling. River levels will remain high over the next few days and sensitive to further rainfall. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.  This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Court Meadow, Kempsey and Callow End
items.message:
River levels remain high but steady at the Kempsey Yacht Club river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. We expect flooding to affect Court Meadow Caravan Park. 

Peak:- Kempsey Yacht Club peaked at 7.26m on Wednesday evening, 03/01/24.

We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 

This message will be updated by 5pm today, Friday 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent at Lenton for Nottingham Park and Ride Site at Queens Drive
items.message:

Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until Sunday 07/01/2024.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please follow advice from emergency services and avoid contact with flood water.  If you have been flooded, please contact your insurance provider
This message will be updated by 18:00 on 06/01/23, or as the situation changes."

items.description: River Wharfe at Ryther

items.description: Sandown, Brading and Bembridge on the Eastern Yar
items.message: Water levels in the Eastern Yar remain high. Levels at Sandown are rising, and will continue to rise until 17:00 this evening (05/01/2024). Currently, there is extensive out of bank flooding through the Yar Valley. Moreton Common and Golf Links Road are flooded. Impacts are expected at Fort Holiday Park and Sandown sewage works as ditches struggle to drain to the main river. Impacts are also expected at Nicholas Close, Brading. This is following yesterday's rain as 27mm was recorded at Wroxhall, which is a significant amount of rain in a short period of time. This is in addition to the prolonged rainfall which has been affecting the area over the last few months. Bembridge sluice is operating normally. We continue to monitor levels and will ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Please ensure any products used to protect gardens and property from flooding are operating. The next five days are forecast to be mainly dry. This Flood Warning will be updated by 12:00 on 06/01/2024.

items.description: River Ouse at York - Skeldergate and Tower Street
items.message: This warning has been removed as levels have fallen below levels of concern. We will continue to monitor and reissue this warning if necessary.

items.description: River Trent at Farndon riverside properties including Dorner Avenue and Wyke and Marsh Lane

Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until Saturday 06/01/2024.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please follow advice from emergency services and avoid contact with flood water. Have a bag ready with vital items like medicines and insurance documents.
This message will be updated by 18:00 on 06/01/23, or as the situation changes."

items.description: River Trent at Newark for riverside properties
items.message:
River levels are high but slowly falling at the Colwick Gauge as a result of Storm Henk. Consequently, flooding is expected to continue. Areas most at risk are Newark Riverside Properties.
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high until Saturday, 06/01/2024.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please follow advice from emergency services and avoid contact with flood water. If you have been flooded, please contact your insurance provider.
This message will be updated by 23:00 tonight, 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ouse at York - Fulford and Fordlands Road
items.message: This warning has been removed as levels have fallen below levels of concern. We will continue to monitor and reissue this warning if necessary.

items.description: River Trent at Dunham-on-Trent
items.message:
River levels are rising at the Torksey river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently the risk of flooding remains . Areas most at risk are the A57 Dunham Road Bridge at Dunham-on-Trent. Property is not expected to flood at this stage.

Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Please move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety and turn off gas, electricity and water. Contact your insurance provider if you've been flooded.

This message will be updated by 18:00 on 05/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and its tributaries from Days Lock to above Pangbourne

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thames, Lady Brook, Ewelme Stream, Mill Brook, West Hagbourne Stream, Hakkas Brook, Cholsey Brook, Kibble Ditch

items.message: Property flooding is expected. There is a Flood Warning in force for the River Thames between Days Lock and South Stoke. River levels are high and rising slowly on the River Thames as a result of recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue over the next few days, especially in the areas closest to the river between Shillingford and Pangbourne. This morning is forecast to be mainly dry, followed by further showers this evening and overnight which have the potential to be heavy at times. We expect river levels to continue to rise slowly over the next few days as water makes its way downstream. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Bourne and tributaries
items.message: River levels continue to rise on the River Bourne at Tidworth Manor Bridge and Salisbury Bourne river gauges due to rainfall.  Areas most at risk include tributaries between Aughton and Laverstock.  There is further heavy rainfall forecast for today. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels in the area.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Consider activating any property flood protection products you may have. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. This message will be updated by 5:00 PM on 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: Groundwater levels in villages surrounding Andover are high and rising. In the last 7 days, nearly a month’s rain (65mm) has been recorded at Andover. Groundwater is affecting cellars in Appleshaw, Hatherden, and Penton Grafton. The spring at Biddesden is now flowing and this will affect the sewerage system in Appleshaw. Groundwater emergence into Deacon and Down Road, Kimpton is likely to have just started. The weather forecast for the next five days is for relatively small amounts of rain. However, there is a possibility that heavy rain (45mm) could be recorded in Hampshire on Thursday (04/01/2024). Groundwater is expected to rise until mid-January 2024, and could rise quickly if heavy rain affects the area. Cellar flooding in Kimpton and surface water flood risk in Thruxton is possible from Saturday (06/01/2024). In Appleshaw, widespread impacts including road flooding could be possible next week. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 10/01/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hursley
items.message: In Hursley, groundwater levels are high and rising. In the last 7 days, more than half a month’s rain (49mm) has been recorded at Otterbourne. Groundwater levels in Hursley have risen by 58cm during that time. A significant number of properties in the village are now expected to be experiencing cellar flooding and impacts to the sewerage system. The weather forecast for the next five days is for relatively small amounts of rain. However, there is a possibility that heavy rain (45mm) could be recorded in Hampshire on Thursday (04/01/2024). Groundwater levels will remain high and responsive to rainfall.  If we receive very heavy rainfall on Thursday it is possible that groundwater levels may reach the threshold where we expect to see internal property flooding within the next week. We continue to monitor the forecast and groundwater levels. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 10/01/2024.

items.description: River Darent from Westerham to Dartford
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall on the River Darent near Westerham and Otford.
River levels are forecast to rise on the River Darent near Hawley as water flows downstream, and levels will stay high throughout today (05/01/2024) and tomorrow (06/01/2024).
Flooding is possible on low lying land and roads from 5:00 PM today.
No property flooding is expected and no further heavy rainfall is forecast.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 8:00 PM on 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Arun
items.message: The River Arun is high and rising near Pulborough, following Thursday's rain. Flood water could affect properties at Pallingham Lock from 10:00 05/01/2024. The river could also affect the A272 Newbridge road near Billingshurst. In Horsham, river levels are already falling. Minor flood impacts will continue to affect gardens of Tanbridge Park and Blackbridge Court and fields behind Arunside, Horsham. Flood water will continue to affect isolated mill properties, fields and roads between Broadbridge Heath and Loxwood, but river levels here are also falling. Very little rain is forecast for the next five days. The river should begin to fall by 20:00 05/01/2024 near Pallingham Quay, where flood minor impacts could remain through the weekend. Between Horsham and Rudgwick, the river should return nearer to normal by Saturday. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Wanford as a precaution, if you have them. Our automatic sluice at Provender Mill is operating to help reduce the risk of flooding through Horsham. We will update this message by 16:00 06/01/2024.

items.description: River Thames for Shiplake, Lower Shiplake and Wargrave
items.message:
River levels remain very high on the River Thames as a result of a period of sustained rain.  Flooding of property and low lying land is expected to continue. The forecast for today (05/01/24) is for mostly dry conditions with the chance of some light showers tonight.  Levels will continue to slowly rise over the next 24 hours.                                                                                                                              A Flood Warning remains in force for the River Thames at Shiplake, Lower Shiplake and Wargrave.  

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lox
items.message: The River Lox is high, but now slowly falling following Thursday's rain (04/01/2024). Minor flood impacts affecting fields, roads and gardens will continue along the length of the River Lox, including gardens of isolated riverside properties at Loxley Bridge on Wrotham Hill, Dunsfold and on Petworth Road, Chiddingfold. Flood water could be close to properties near Brewhurst Mill on Brewhurst Lane, and the garden of the Onslow Arms, Loxwood. Very little rain is forecast for the next five days. The river should continue to fall, and return to a more normal level by Saturday (06/01/2024). Please continue to operate private water control structures at Brewhurst, to reduce the risk of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 15:00 on 06/01/2024.

items.description: River Wye in Herefordshire
items.message:
River levels continue to fall on the River Wye but remain high as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads & farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye from Hay on Wye to Ross on Wye. Other locations that may be affected include the A438, Byford, Bredwardine & Hereford. 
Actual peaks:- 
Hay on Wye peaked at 3.91m on Tuesday evening, 02/01/24, 
Bredwardine peaked at 6.21m Wednesday morning, 03/01/24. 
Belmont peaked at 5.86m on Wednesday evening, 03/01/2024. 
Old Wye Bridge peaked at 5.18m on Wednesday evening, 03/01/24. 
Mordiford peaked at 5.24m on Wednesday evening, 03/01/2024.  
Ross on Wye peaked at 4.81m on Thursday morning 04/01/24. 
Some showers are forecast today, 05/01/24, but no further significant rainfall is expected. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 10am on Saturday 06/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Wye in Gloucestershire
items.message:
River levels are now beginning to fall at the Ross-On-Wye and Lydbrook river gauges, but levels remain high as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye. 
Actual Peaks; Ross on Wye peaked at 4.81m and Lydbrook peaked at 6.75m on Thursday morning, 04/01/24
Some showers are forecast today, 05/01/24, but no further significant rainfall is expected. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 10am on Saturday 06/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Roach, Prittle Brook and Eastwood Brook
items.message: River levels are now steadily falling, but still remain quite high in some locations. The forecast is for drier conditions into the weekend. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected, although levels may reach flood warning in the afternoon of 06/01/24. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue for the next few days, especially in areas closest to the river downstream of Purley and between Purley and Sonning. This morning is forecast to be mainly dry, followed by further showers this evening and overnight which have the potential to be heavy at times.  We expect river levels to continue to rise slowly over the next few days as water makes its way downstream. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.  This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

Please avoid driving or walking through floodwater. Further isolated showers are forecast throughout Friday 5th January. We expect river levels to remain high throughout the day. Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. This message will be updated by 9pm on Friday 5th January, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle River Medway
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels remain high following heavy rainfall during the last 24 hours. Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads at Tonbridge playing fields and town centre car parks, through to Tudeley, East Peckham and Yalding. This is likely to include the sports pitches, also known as the racecourse, in Tonbridge and Postern Lane. Flooding of Lees Road at Laddingford, The Lees at Yalding and Little Venice park at Yalding is likely on Friday 5 January. River levels are expected to peak in Yalding on Friday evening or the early hours of Saturday morning. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Further isolated showers are forecast throughout Friday 5 January. We expect river levels to remain high into Saturday 6 January. Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. This message will be updated by 9pm on Friday 5 January, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hoe Stream

The forecast for today (05/01/24) is for mostly dry conditions with the chance of some light showers tonight.  Levels have stopped rising and are expected to slowly fall over the next 24 hours.                                                                                                                                                      A Flood Warning remains in force for the Hoe Stream at Woking                                                                                                               

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the North Winterborne, north of the A354
items.message:
Groundwater levels at the Delcombe Wood borehole have risen in response to recent heavy rainfall and will continue to do so for the next few days. Flooding of roads and some properties, especially basements is expected. 
Residents should deploy any property resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers.
Driving through flood water will be especially dangerous as temperatures will drop to below freezing at times over the next week and will cause ice to form on roads. The bow wave from vehicles can flood adjacent properties and lead to icing of pavements.
Sewage systems may become overloaded. Do not lift manhole covers to alleviate local surface water flooding as this may cause toilets further downhill to surcharge.
This message will be updated on Saturday the 6th January, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Pangbourne to Purley
items.message: Property flooding is expected. A flood warning is in force for the River Thames at Purley. River levels are high and rising slowly on the River Thames as a result of recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land, roads and property is expected to continue for the next few days, especially in the Mapledurham, Purley and Pangbourne areas. This morning is forecast to be mainly dry, followed by further showers this evening and overnight which have the potential to be heavy at times. We expect river levels to continue to rise slowly over the next few days as water makes its way downstream. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.  This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Bere Stream
items.message:
Groundwater levels at Delcombe Wood borehole have risen in response to recent heavy rainfall and will continue to do so for the next few days. Flooding of roads and some properties, especially basements is expected. 
Residents should deploy any property resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers.
Driving through flood water will be especially dangerous as temperatures will drop to below freezing at times over the next week and will cause ice to form on roads. The bow wave from vehicles can flood adjacent properties and lead to icing of pavements.
Sewage systems may become overloaded. Do not lift manhole covers to alleviate local surface water flooding as this may cause toilets further downhill to surcharge.
This message will be updated on Saturday the 6th January, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Hanley Road, Upton upon Severn
items.message:
River levels remain high but steady at the Saxons Lode river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect property at Hanley Road, Upton upon Severn. Hanley Road closes. 

Peak:- Saxons Lode peaked at 5.48m on Thursday afternoon, 04/01/2024.

We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Meon Valley from East Meon to Soberton
items.message: In the Meon Valley, groundwater levels are high and have started to rise again following the recent wet weather. In the last 7 days, more than half a month’s rain (54mm) has been recorded at Warnford. At Pound Lane, the groundwater level has risen by 14cm in the last 24 hours. The Winterbourne is flowing in Meonstoke. From Sunday (07/01/2024), the Winterbourne could begin flowing across Rectory Lane and a small amount of water will pond around the electricity sub-station. The weather forecast for the next five days is for relatively small amounts of rain. However, there is a possibility that heavy rain (45mm) could be recorded in Hampshire on Thursday (04/01/2024). Groundwater levels are expected to continue rising until the weekend, and could rise for longer if further heavy rain affects the area. Cellar flooding caused by groundwater remains a possibility this winter. Please remain prepared. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 10/01/2024.

Levels will continue to slowly rise over the next 24 hours and beyond.

items.description: Groundwater flooding south of the Humber Estuary
items.message: Over the past few weeks we have seen heavy and prolonged rainfall across North Lincolnshire. This means that the groundwater levels in Barrow upon Humber are now rising. This is a developing situation and this may lead to flooding of low lying land which could lead to standing water seen for several days or weeks. Groundwater flooding can be distinguished from river flooding as it will often be clear and is unlikely to flow. This message will be updated online and on Floodline by 16:00 on 6th January 2024, or before if the situation changes.

Residents should deploy any property resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers.
Driving through flood water will be especially dangerous as temperatures will drop to below freezing at times over the next week and will cause ice to form on roads. The bow wave from vehicles can flood adjacent properties and lead to icing of pavements.

items.description: The upper Stour and surrounding tributaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely this morning Friday 5th January 2024.  River levels are currently high as the river responds to current rainfall.  River levels will likely continue to rise this morning in response to further rain but then fall quickly today.  The forecast is for showers to get more scattered and less intense as we move into more settled weather.  Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We are monitoring the situation closely.  We will update this message tomorrow, Saturday 6th January.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Twyford and Hensting
items.message: In Twyford and Hensting, groundwater levels are high and rising. In the last 7 days, more than half a month’s rain (49mm) has been recorded at Otterbourne. From Sunday (07/01/2024), we expect cellar flooding to begin to affect a small number of properties in Twyford and Hensting. The weather forecast for the next five days is for relatively small amounts of rain. However, there is a possibility that heavy rain (45mm) could be recorded in Hampshire on Thursday (04/01/2024). Groundwater levels are expected to continue rising into the middle of next week. We continue to monitor the forecast and groundwater levels. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 10/01/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Vernham Dean, Upton and the Bourne Valley
items.message: In the Bourne Valley, groundwater levels are high and rising. In the last 7 days, nearly a month’s rain (65mm) has been recorded at Andover. In Vernham Dean, the current groundwater rate of rise is 17cm per day. Groundwater is affecting the sewerage network in Stoke. Groundwater levels remain high in Upton and could soon start impacting cellars and the sewerage network. We do not expect significant impacts to property at Vernham Dean, Hurstbourne Tarrant, Stoke or St Marybourne for the next couple of weeks. The weather forecast for the next five days is for relatively small amounts of rain. However, there is a possibility that heavy rain (45mm) could be recorded in Hampshire on Thursday (04/01/2024). Groundwater is expected to rise until mid-January 2024, and could rise quickly if heavy rain affects the valley. We continue to monitor the forecast. In Upton, if you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. We advise all residents remain prepared for flooding impacts this winter. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 10/01/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Bramdean and Cheriton
items.message: In Bramdean and Cheriton, groundwater levels are high and rising. In the last 7 days, more than half a month’s rain (57mm) has been recorded at Bishops Sutton. Cellar flooding is expected to be affecting isolated properties in Cheriton. It is unlikely that cellar flooding will affect property in Bramdean for at least a couple of weeks. The weather forecast for the next five days is for relatively small amounts of rain. However, there is a possibility that heavy rain (45mm) could be recorded in Hampshire on Thursday (04/01/2024). Groundwater levels are expected to continue rising into the middle of next week. We continue to monitor the forecast and groundwater levels. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 10/01/2024.

Further light rainfall is expected over the next 12 hours which will keep river levels high. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate.  We will update this message by 5pm today, 05/01/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in East Kent
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: Groundwater levels in East Kent have risen following recent higher than average rainfall and are expected to remain high until Spring 2024. The Alkham Bourne and the Nailbourne between Lyminge and Littlebourne are flowing. Flows in the Little Stour between Littlebourne and Stourmouth have increased over the Christmas period. Localised flooding may affect low-lying land, roads, and water infrastructure in and around the Elham Valley, Alkham, and Petham. Other communities in East Kent may also be impacted. Please avoid walking or driving through flood water. Heavy rain is forecast across Kent on Thursday 4th January. More settled conditions are expected over the weekend. We are monitoring the situation and are working with local authorities and communities with deployment of temporary defences, such as Canterbury City Council’s temporary defences in Barham. Our staff are maintaining and clearing key structures. This message will be updated by Thursday 11 January 2024, or as the situation changes. Search ‘Kent Groundwater Situation’ on gov.uk.

items.description: River Wissey in Norfolk
items.message: River levels are falling but remain responsive following heavy rainfall overnight. Areas most at risk are those around the River Wissey from Bradenham to Denver including Watton Brook. We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 5pm today, 05/01/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kings Somborne and Little Somborne
items.message: Groundwater levels in Kings Somborne and Little Somborne remain high with the Somborne Stream continuing to flow through Kings Somborne. In the last 7 days, more than half a month’s rain (63mm) has been recorded at Broughton but for the next five days relatively small amounts of rain are forecast. In the coming week, we expect groundwater levels in Kings Somborne to remain high and the Somborne Stream to rise further up the valley. There is an increasing risk of cellar flooding. On Thursday (04/01/2024), there is a possibility that heavy rain (45mm) could be recorded in Hampshire which will cause a more rapid rise in groundwater levels, further increasing the risk of cellar and road flooding. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 10/01/2024.

items.message: River levels are high on the River Bourne due to raised groundwater levels and the recent rainfall. This Flood Warning has been issued because flooding is expected. Flooding could occur at Luggershall Road and Penning Road North of Plassey Close in Tidworth and at High St Junction with Bulford Road in Shipton Bellinger. Further rain is forecast for this afternoon and we will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary. items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Candovers and Old Alresford
items.message: In Preston Candover and Alresford, groundwater levels are high and rising. In the last 3 months, prolonged, much higher than average rainfall (444mm) has been recorded at Bishop’s Sutton. At Preston Candover, groundwater is rising by 10cm per day. From Monday 01/01/2024 in Preston Candover, a small number of properties will experience cellar flooding. At Old Alresford, rising groundwater will reduce the ability of septic tanks to operate properly. Further wet weather is forecast on Monday (01/01/2024) and Tuesday (02/01/2024) with up to 30mm of rain forecast per day. Groundwater levels are expected to continue to rise until at least mid-January 2024. Internal flooding to an isolated property in Old Alresford could be possible in the next 2 weeks. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Friday 05/01/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Bishops Sutton
items.message: In Bishop’s Sutton, groundwater levels are high and rising. In the last 3 months, prolonged, much higher than average rainfall (444mm) has been recorded at Bishop’s Sutton. In the last 24 hours, the groundwater level has risen by 4cm. In the next 2 weeks, cellar flooding will commence in Bishop’s Sutton. Groundwater will begin affecting septic tanks and roads such as the B3047 will start to be impacted, especially after it rains. Further wet weather is forecast on Monday (01/01/2024) and Tuesday (02/01/2024) with up to 30mm of rain forecast per day. Groundwater levels are expected to continue to rise until at least mid-January 2024. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by Friday 05/01/2024.

Our incident room is open and we are closely monitoring the situation. Further showers are forecast for the next few days, before drier more settled weather arrives from Sunday. Put your flood plan into action and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 08:00 PM on Friday 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Isolated properties near the River Nene from Cogenhoe to Great Doddington
items.message: Heavy rain over the past week in the River Nene catchment has fallen onto already saturated ground. This has caused the River Nene to rise. Low lying areas near to the River Nene are already flooded. Further rainfall last night and this morning is causing the river levels to increase again today and remain high. No further significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days. Isolated properties and villages close to the river between Cogenhoe and Great Doddington are most at risk. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings. Please avoid contact with flood water. Our staff are out in the area to check the flood defences, clear blockages, and assist the emergency services and council. We will be closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 16:00 on 6th January, or before if the situation changes.

Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours. We expect river levels to remain high until Saturday, 06/01/2024.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid contact with flood water. If you have been flooded, please contact your insurance provider.
This message will be updated by 19:00 this evening, 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Bourne Valley - The Winterbournes
items.message:
Groundwater levels at the Queen Manor Farm borehole have risen in response to recent heavy rainfall and will continue to do so for the next few days. Flooding of roads and some properties, especially basements is expected. 
Residents should deploy any property resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers.
Driving through flood water will be especially dangerous as temperatures will drop to below freezing at times over the next week and will cause ice to form on roads. The bow wave from vehicles can flood adjacent properties and lead to icing of pavements.
Sewage systems may become overloaded. Do not lift manhole covers to alleviate local surface water flooding as this may cause toilets further downhill to surcharge.
This message will be updated on Saturday the 6th January, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Datchet to Shepperton Green
items.message:
River levels remain very high on the River Thames as a result of a period of sustained rain.  Flooding of property and low lying land is expected to continue. The forecast for today (05/01/24) is for mostly dry conditions with the chance of some light showers tonight.  Levels will continue to slowly rise over the next 24 hours and beyond.                                                                                                                              Flood Warnings remains in force for the River Thames at Laleham and Properties closest to the River Thames at Old Windsor from Friday Island to Magna Carter Island. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lodsbridge to Shopham Bridge on the Western Rother
items.message: The Western Rother is rising following 30mm of rainfall on Thursday (04/01/2024). Flood water will continue to affect properties at Lodsbridge, near Selham, and could also affect the A285 and properties at Coultershaw Bridge, near Petworth. Flood water will be extensive through fields and also affect gardens and rural roads. River levels on the Lod are already slowly falling, so minor flood impacts should reduce on the Lod, near Lickfold Bridge, Highstead Lane and at Halfway Bridge. Very little rain is forecast for the next five days. The river should begin to fall by 14:00 on 05/01/2024, and return nearer to normal levels by Sunday (07/01/2024). Flood protection products are recommended to be installed at Lodsbridge, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 14:00 on 06/01/2024.

items.message: River levels are falling, but remain high following heavy rainfall overnight. Areas most at risk are around Bin Brook, at Newnham in Cambridge. items.description: River Severn at Bewdley, Blackstone and Stourport
items.message:
River levels are rising at the Bewdley river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect Riverside North. 

Peaks:- Bewdley peaked at 4.8m on Tuesday evening, 02/01/24. A second predicted peak of 5.1m to 5.2m is expected on Friday evening 05/01/24, as a result of additional rainfall within the catchment.

We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and Local Authorities. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety. 

This message will be updated by 9am, Saturday 06/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle Avon from Salisbury to Ringwood
items.message: River levels are high and forecast to rise further on the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon due to further rainfall forecast for today. Areas most at risk include areas in Britford, Charlton All Saints, Downton and Fordingbridge in close proximity to the River Avon. We will continue to monitor levels closely and continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your surroundings. This message will be updated by 4pm on the 05/01/24,  or as the situation changes

items.description: River Thame at Dorchester
items.message: Property flooding is expected. River levels are continuing to rise on the River Thame following heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of property and roads is expected to continue today, 05/01/2024, especially in the Dorchester area. This morning is forecast to be mainly dry, followed by further showers this evening and overnight which have the potential to be heavy at times. We expect river levels to continue gradually rising today as water makes its way downstream. Levels will remain sensitive to further rainfall, and may rise further in response to forecast rainfall. We are monitoring the situation. Activate any property flood protection products such as flood barriers. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Be aware of flooded roads, do not drive through floodwater. This message will be updated this evening, 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at the Wharfage, Ironbridge
items.message:
River levels are high but beginning to fall at the Buildwas river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect Phase 2 of the Temporary Flood Barriers along the Wharfage. The barriers are operational and have water against them. The deployment of the barriers does not remove all risk, as the barrier system is a temporary structure and can not be guaranteed to perform. The Environment Agency may need to withdraw from behind the defences due to site circumstances.
Actual peak:- Buildwas 6.35m Thursday evening, 04/01/24.
Some heavy showers are forecast today, 05/01/24, but no further significant rainfall is expected. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with Local Authorities. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated by 7pm on Friday 05/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message: Groundwater levels are high and gradually rising at our observation borehole at Northfield Farm near Great Shefford in response to recent rainfall across the area.  Groundwater levels are higher than normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may now be affected by flooding from groundwater within the next few days. The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. Low-lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 12/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Langney Haven
items.message: The Langney Haven is higher than normal, following persistent rain since the New Year, and intense rain on Thursday. Minor flood impacts will continue to affect gardens of properties in Langney Green. Fields and parkland including Shinewater Park will also be affected by flood water. Very little rain is forecast for the next five days. The river will continue to rise after each high tide, but should now peak a little lower each time. Minor flood impacts could remain until Sunday. The river will remain higher than normal for most of next week. Please take proactive action to help reduce the impact of flooding. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed at Langney Green, if you have them. We are operating our structures at Fence Bridge and Crumbles Gate to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 16:00 06/01/2024.

items.description: Swaton Eau in Swaton Village
items.message: The Swaton Eau has been falling steadily today, Thursday 4th January and we do not expect any further flooding to properties. There may be standing water in low lying areas and fields for several days.

items.description: Heighington Beck in Heighington
items.message: Heavy rain over the past week in the Heighington Beck catchment has fallen onto already saturated ground. This caused the Beck to rise. Low lying areas near to the rivers are flooded. No significant further rainfall is forecast, however we expect the river levels to remain high for the next few days. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings. Please avoid contact with flood water. Our staff are out in the area to check the flood defences, clear blockages, and assist the emergency services and council. We will be closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 16:00 on 6th January, or before if the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels are remaining high on the Colne, due to heavy rainfall. 
Flooding is forecast to continue to affect locations near the Colne, with low lying land most affected, particularly around Moor Lane Cottages, Bushey Hall Lane, Carpenders Park, Frogmore Cottages, Lower High Street, Rickmansworth, Batchworth, Watford, and Oxhey. 
We expect river levels to remain high throughout the day but no further significant rainfall is forecast. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 
This message will be updated this evening, on Friday 5th January, or as the situation changes

items.description: River Coln and its tributaries
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high and slowly rising on the River Coln following recent rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 04/01/2024, and overnight especially in the Fairford area. Further rainfall is forecast to move through the area during the afternoon and overnight 04/01/2024 before conditions become drier into the weekend. We expect river levels to remain high over the coming days and will remain sensitive to further rainfall. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.  This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 05/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ash in Hertfordshire
items.message:
River levels on the Ash are high due to heavy rainfall yesterday. 
No property flooding is expected.
River levels have been high at Furneux Pelham, Little Hadham, and Mardock but have now peaked or are dropping.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated this evening on Friday 5th January, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Shrewsbury
items.message:
River levels are high but continue to fall slowly at the Welshbridge river gauge. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect Gravel Hill lane, Sydney Avenue & Victoria Avenue. Frankwell car park and St Julians Friars car park are flooded. The land behind wall at Coton Hill and the B5067 Berwick Road are also impacted by flooding.  

Welshbridge peaked at 4.69m on Thursday morning 04/01/24. 
Some heavy showers are forecast today, 05/01/24, but no further significant rainfall is expected. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 7pm on Friday 05/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Barlings Eau in Langworth

Flooding is impacting locations near the Stort, Stanstead Brook, and Pishiobury Brook.
River levels are at high at Grange Paddocks, Sawbridgeworth, Harlow Mill, Pishiobury Brook, and Glen Faba gauges.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated this evening on Friday 5th January, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Upper Arley
items.message:
River levels have peaked and are beginning to fall slowly at the Bridgnorth river gauge following recent heavy rainfall. 
Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in and around Upper Arley. 
Actual peak: Bridgnorth 4.90m, this morning, 05/01/24 at 2:15am.
Some heavy showers are forecast today, 05/01/24, but no further significant rainfall is expected. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.
We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low-lying land.  Further light rainfall is possible over the next 24 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation closely.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please avoid contact with flood water and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to Cherwell Bridge
items.message: Property flooding is possible. River levels are high but slowly dropping on the River Cherwell following heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of property and roads remains possible today, 05/01/2024, especially in the Enslow area. Areas most at risk are properties in Mill End and Watermead Road in Kidlington, and properties closest to the river in Enslow. This morning is forecast to be mainly dry, followed by further showers this evening and overnight which have the potential to be heavy at times. River levels are expected to continue falling today, but will remain sensitive to further rainfall. River levels will remain high over the coming days as water moves down the catchment. We are monitoring the situation. Activate any property flood protection products such as flood barriers. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Be aware of flooded roads, do not drive through floodwater. This message will be updated this evening, 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary.

items.description: River Cherwell from below Banbury to just above Upper Heyford
items.message: Property flooding is possible. River levels have continued to drop on the River Cherwell following recent heavy rainfall but may rise again in response to rainfall overnight, 04/01/2024. Therefore, flooding of property and roads remains possible overnight and into tomorrow, 05/01/2024, especially in the Kings Sutton area. Areas most at risk are properties in Wales Street Kings Sutton.  This morning is forecast to be mainly dry, followed by further showers this evening and overnight which have the potential to be heavy at times. We expect river levels to continue steadily dropping overnight,  but may rise again in response to forecast rainfall and water moving down the catchment during the day tomorrow, 05/01/2024. We are monitoring the situation. Be aware of flood water remaining on the floodplain. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Be aware of flooded roads, do not drive through floodwater. This message will be updated this evening, 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Nene in Wellingborough
items.message: Heavy rain over the past week in the River Nene catchment has fallen onto already saturated ground. This has caused the River Nene to rise. Low lying areas near to the river are already flooded. Further rainfall last night and this morning is causing the river levels to increase again today and remain high. No further significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days.  Properties on Irthlingborough Road in Wellingborough are most at risk. Please avoid contact with flood water. Our staff are out in the area to check the flood defences, clear blockages, and assist the emergency services and council. We will be closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 16:00 on 6th January, or before if the situation changes.

items.message: River levels on the lower River Ouse are falling slowly but remain high as a result of recent heavy rainfall associated with Storm Henk. Flooding is expected to affect locations near the River Ouse, particularly roads and properties around Acaster Selby. There is an ongoing risk of flooding to gardens, roads and paths, but risk to properties is expected to continue falling. Levels are expected to remain high for the next few days but to continue falling with drier weather expected over the coming days. Continue acting on your flood plan where it is safe to do so. Our incident room is open and we are closely monitoring the situation. Monitor river levels and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 6:00PM on Friday 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Holderness Drain at Routh and Meaux
items.message: Levels remain high on Holderness Drain and Monk Dyke due to recent heavy rainfall. Flooding is possible along Holderness Drain, Monk Dyke, Routh and Meaux Drains. We are operating pumps in the area, however the catchment remains very wet. Further showers are expected over the next few days, before drier more settled weather arrives next week. Levels are expected to remain high for a number of days. Our incident room remains open, and we are closely monitoring the situation. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 06:30 PM on Friday 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

Avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses, and do not drive through floodwater. This message will be updated by 23:45 on 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising steadily in response to recent rainfall.  The forecast is for predominantly dry conditions for the next few days with some isolated showers possible.  Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message tomorrow, Saturday 6th January 2024.

items.description: The Rivers Pant, Blackwater and Brain
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today Friday 5th January 2024. River levels are currently high as the river responds to overnight rainfall.  River levels will likely continue to rise this morning. The forecast is for showers to get more scattered and less intense as we move into drier weather over the weekend.  Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation closely.  We will update this message tomorrow, Saturday 6th January.

items.description: River Severn at Minsterworth and Stonebench
items.message:
River levels are rising at the Gloucester river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible. Properties may be affected in and around Minsterworth Ham and Stonebench.

Predicted peak:- Gloucester docks, 4.6m to 4.7m this morning, Friday 05/01/2024.

We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services and Local Authorities. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded, and avoid contact with flood water.

This message will be updated by 7pm today, Friday 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames at Purley Village
items.message: Property flooding is expected. River levels are high and slowly rising on the River Thames as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land, roads and property is expected to continue today, 05/01/2024, especially in the River Gardens, Chestnut Grove and Wintringham areas of Purley. This morning is forecast to be mainly dry, followed by further showers this evening and overnight which have the potential to be heavy at times. We expect river levels to continue rising over the next 48 hours as water makes its way downstream. We are monitoring the situation. Activate any property flood protection products such as flood barriers. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Be aware of flooded roads, do not drive through floodwater. This message will be updated this evening, 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 7pm today, Friday 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent at riverside areas of Burton upon Trent
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Drakelow river gauge.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Flooding is affecting properties around Waterside Road area in Stapenhill, Burton Bridge area, Newton Road area in Winshill and Church Lane in Newton Solney.    
No further rain is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until Friday evening, 05/01/2024.
Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast and checking defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water, take photographs of any flood damage, and call 999 if in immediate danger.
This message will be updated Friday morning, 05/01/2024, or as the situation changes.
